sentence: NEW YORK, April 10 (Reuters Breakingviews) - Zoom Video Communications really is as rare as a unicorn.
Not only is it a multibillion-dollar technology company going public in 2019, it even makes money - unlike better known debutants like ride-hailing services Lyft and Uber Technologies .
Yet with valuation multiples sky-high, Zoom's initial public offering pits greed against America's suspicions of tech in China.
Zoom's creation story explains some of its success.
Founder Eric Yuan worked at WebEx Communications, a video-conferencing firm Cisco acquired for $3.2 billion in 2007.
The clunky service was an affront to him, as the engineer explains in the prospectus.
That isn't a problem with his new firm, as users flock to its software.
Strong growth looks assured for several years, as trial users often end up subscribing and convincing colleagues to join.
Moreover, Zoom is starting to tap overseas markets.
When it comes to making money, having over 500 employees in China, or nearly a third of the total, surely helps.
That's where the firm does most of its product development.

Suppose Zoom pays its Chinese engineers, say, $50,000 a year while the price of an American equivalent is $150,000, that's $50 million of annual savings, assuming the employees are equally productive.
Combine fast growth with this ability to keep a lid on costs, and Zoom will probably have one of the higher valuations in cloud-software companies.
At the top of the indicated range, Zoom will be valued at approaching 30 times last year's revenue.
That's around what collaboration-software darling Atlassian is valued at, and more than twice the multiple attached to Salesforce.com .
Yet the China angle could become a problem.
Theft of intellectual property remains troubling in the People's Republic.
And U.S. IP and cyber-security worries could cast suspicion over communications products designed there, in the same way Chinese hardware supplier Huawei is under scrutiny in the West.
Having to relocate Zoom's engineering effort would certainly make Yuan, and investors, unhappy.
The firm's China-centered R&D effort is a selling point, but it also brings significant political risk.
- Zoom Video Communications on April 8 filed a revised draft prospectus for its upcoming initial public offering, giving a price range of $28 to $32 per share.
The online video-conferencing firm plans to sell 11 million new Class A shares, and existing investors hope to sell 10 million.
In addition, Salesforce.com has agreed to buy $100 million of shares in a private placement at the same price as the IPO.
- At the top of the indicated range, Zoom would have a diluted market capitalization of about $9.5 billion, assuming the underwriters' overallotment is exercised.
- Zoom had $331 million of revenue in the year to January 2019, an increase of 118 percent from the prior year.
The company reported $7.6 million of income in the most recent year, reversing a loss of $3.8 million the previous year.
- Zoom had 1,702 full-time employees at the end of January.
Over 500 of these employees were in China, where the company has research and development centers.
